Light platformer and puzzle game with a fantastic sense of humor. The puzzles are just enough to get you scratching your head, but not so hard that you get frustrated and want to quit; it's the perfect balance. Entertaining story along the way with a little twist. Graphics are still pretty good by today's standards, sound effects are nice, and the music is fitting. Totally worth buying.

One of the best games I've ever played.

I'm a potato!
Great puzzle story game with some great animations and more

Portal 2 is a game that requires time and effort. If you can't put in the time, don't bother. Each level and test requires you to remember past skills and events, and a lot of heavy thinking. 

Some attributes of this game will require some memory of the original Portal game, but it is playable even if you have never played or heard of the Portal series before. Although, it does help to have knowledge of the original game. It always helps.

The game itself is super fun! Even if you don't play the optional cooperative mode, even singleplayer is a heap of work. Don't feel bad if you need to look up some walkthroughs on how to finish a level, but try not to, it ruins the fun, most of the time (being stuck on a level for a few hours because it requires some super hard trick to do is always an exception).

All in all I highly recommend everyone to play this game. Is it worth the 20$ US Price tag however, is a different story. I would buy it at full price, but I do recommend you buy it either on sale or through 3rd party websites (such as G2A) in a package with Portal 1. Either way, this valve game will always remain a classic, just like the Half Life series.

The story for Portal 2 was outstanding.  I was't expecting much honestly, I just wanted more puzzles with my portal gun.  But right from the start we get this humorous Wheatley robot that guides us around the complex and then the story turns really intense and exciting.  Every aspect of the game complimented each other.  The music, sound effects, and voice acting were all so amazing and I'm listening to the very last song as I write this review.  The developers took no short cuts in this one, and this is one of the few sequels that I can honestly say is better than the original.  No experience required from the first game to absolutely enjoy Portal 2!

I would make a Pros/Cons list but I can't think of anything I really disliked about the game.  So, there you go.

Можно купить игры по скидке, но своих начальных денег она стоит, хоть я ее сначала и спиратил, но когда купил-не пожалел

Having the two robots makes it easier to do more complex jumps with team work.  Along with unlimited custom mods for tons of fun in the Steam Workshop.  Overall Rating 10/10 as it gave the users what we wanted and even more.  More sequels to games shows that they pay attention to the fan base.

BEST GAME EVER

For me, the best thing about the Portal franchise is how its very premise inspires one's imagination. I'm often fantasizing about how different our society would be, if such quantum physics-bending technology like this actually existed - how the wheel would not only have been re-invented, but ultimately made obsolete. Obviously this premise was wonderfully imagined by Valve's writing and design teams, since the  [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narbacular_Drop]Narbacular Drop[/url] recruits joined Valve after their inspiring project was discovered by Valve, leading to the development of Portal 1.

Portal 2 brilliantly and slowly introduces all new puzzle solving tools and mechanisms, like gel and light-bridges, as the player winds their way through the humorous and increasingly bizarre science-fiction tale, set quite some time after Portal 1's climax. [url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0580351/?ref_=tt_cl_t2]Stephen Merchant[/url] absolutely steals the show voice-acting "Wheatley", a rogue computer personality core who guides the player-controlled "Chell" through an overgrown, time-deprecated Aperture Science underground facility, after she's been sleeping soundly for "999999" days.

Through the first part of story there are unfolding elements and occasional clues that lead to an almost predictable yet entertaining plot twist, during the inevitable confrontation between Chell and "GLaDOS", the nasty facility controlling [spoiler](and destroying)[/spoiler] antagonist from the first game, again perfectly voiced by [url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1655889/?ref_=tt_cl_t1]Ellen McLain[/url]. The twist takes Chell into VERY deep unexplored undergrounds, forgotten by time perhaps for centuries, where both Aperture's and key characters' backstories and history are revealed.

By this point I absolutely knew Valve had another masterpiece on their hands. Portal 2 represents a perfect mesh of game elements, design in both visual and audio areas, and story. It will remain on my hard drive for many, many years as I love going back to this story. I muck around with the built in puzzle creator (a simplistic, community-driven test chamber editor that's easy and fun to explore in itself), and while I cannot in this review encompass the co-op gameply asthetics of Portal 2, since I'm not a big multiplayer gamer and have not attempted it, from what other sources say this can be even much more fun than the single-player campaign.

Portal 2 is a classic. Period. JJ Abrams has even announced work on a Portal film (for which both Merchant and McLean must DEFINITELY sign on for) - let's hope anyway....

10/10.

Favorite game series ever.

Portal 2 is far more refined than its predecessor.

Better graphics.  Granted the game did came out 4 years after.

Better humor.  81 min into the game I must have chuckled 4-5 times at GlaDOS's remarks.

Better physics.  The cube and various objects **feel like** they bear actual weight this time.

Better puzzles.  I no longer get disoriented solving them.

I actually care about Chell, that flying bot with blue eye and of course GlaDOS----this didn't happen while I was playing Portal.

While I'd gave Portal a borderline 6 / 10, I'm inclined to rate Porta 2 at least a 8.5 / 10.
